author: mootley

description.text:
This is the MakerBot MightyBoard, a revolution in 3D Printer Control Technology. Use it to power your MakerBot Replicator 3D Printer. Here are just a few things the MightyBoard can do: control up to 5 stepper motors with BotStep Stepper Controllers, control up to two extruders (with heater cartridges, safety thermostats, thermocouples, and fans), control the Replicator Interface Board, connect to up to 6 endstops, control RGB LED light strips, control a heated build platform, and much much more! Even more features:
-Pizeo Buzzer
-Lots of Debugging LEDs and extra I/O pins broken out for hacking
-Access to I2C and UART for hacking
-Hardware-based safety cutoff for extruders
-Extra FET for hacking
-Arduino Mega Compatible
-digitally-controlled potentiometers for setting motor currents (no more trimpots!) Designed by Jeremy Blum. This is part of The MakerBot Replicator, which you can find at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:18813

comments.text: For fun I'm putting together a proper pins file and example configuration to support this board in Marlin Firmware. I see that the stepper current is controlled through I2C with separate SCL pins for each of the MCP4018s, so I expect that will be the biggest challenge to adapt. I haven't yet found an I2C library that allows for this. If only they were all on the common bus, but it looks like the 4018 is pre-addressed.

comments.text: Yeah my friend saw my comment and mentioned that to me today. I didn't realize how big the cost difference was. I've used Allegro's SPI stepper drivers before, and they are pricey. comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Seems like they should have waited for the Arduino Due ARM-based Arduino. Its got a super powerful Atmel SAM3 on it. But I'm sure they know the people at Arduino, and perhaps that board and software is just not close enough to production?
comments.author: Guest

comments.text: That is because it is a futile exercise how to hobble yourself: there are two micros on there. One is a atmega8, the other is a 1280. The mega8 is serving as a usb to serial controller, and that is where I think they (and arduino) went wrong.
comments.author: Guest

comments.text: Yes, it is indeed somewhat counter-productive to strap two atmels on a board and have one act as a US-serial bridge. I did a quick search on atmel's site to compare the two most powerful AVRs with and without baked-in USB support: the AT90USB1286 and the ATmega2560, as used on an Arduino Mega. The 2560 has higher specs in every discipline, them most significant ones are:
comments.author: JelleBoomstra

comments.text:
So switch over to an ARM. For example the LPC1678 has Gcode support from the Smoothie project and has very similar specs to the ATMega2560 except it's a 32bit processor capable of running at 120MHz. Cost wise the ATMega2560 + ATMega8u2 is
Ã‚Â£9.43 vs the LPC1678 at Ã‚Â£5.44

Maintaining arduino compatibility makes it easier for users to re-purpose the mightyboard and expand its functionality.  As @imitation mentioned, the beefiest USB-capable atmega micro doesn't have enough I/O, hence the need for two.
comments.author: TheFallen

comments.text: But the fact that it's an 8bit microcontroller running at 16MHz with a poor compiler limits the upper bounds of what can be done. Sure, everyone is familiar with a bicycle, but a car can go so much faster.

title: Raspberry Pi Zero LCD brackets
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This Thing provides a pair of brackets to mount an I2C-enabled 16x2 LCD display on a Raspberry Pi Zero. The clips should hold the LCD & Pi Zero securely without needing adhesive. There are two versions of the files. BracketR and bracketL are slightly asymmetrical - these are the originals I used to mount the LCD to a Pi Zero fixed to a small USB hub as shown in the pictures (the Pi Zero is not quite centred on the hub). BracketRs and bracketLs are symmetrical alternatives where the LCD is centred with respect to the Pi Zero. Please use one pair or the other, but don't mix them!

The Pi Zero SD card can be changed without removing the brackets.

Depending on their orientation, it may be necessary to bend the I2C connector pins on the LCD backpack as shown in photo 2. I also recommend using a level shifter to connect the 3.3V logic of the Pi Zero to the 5V LCD.

Printer Brand:

Solidoodle

Printer:

Solidoodle 2 - Expert

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

0.2

Notes:

There's very little infill in the prints, so this can be set to a low value. The STL files include a disconnected 'blob' to prime the extruder as well as blobs on the corners to aid adhesion to the print bed.
You may need to clean up the 'blips' to allow them to slide onto the Pi Zero and LCD pcbs.

Tbuser's Poopin Gnome made me laugh, but he seemed to be missing the top of his hat (too tall for the Makerbot Digitizer?) Time for a remix... Luckily, I found photos of "Squatting Garden Gnome" on Amazon (www.amazon.com/dp/B001E05KPK) and very roughly modelled the hat in Sculptris. Also added more creases to the eyes and beard, and extended the front hat brim (it didn't seem to have scanned as well as the rest of the gnome.)
The whole model was tilted back 15 degrees and the feet squared off with NetFab.
Thanks tbuser!!

Scaled to 35% (78 mm tall) and printed on a Replicator in green ABS using raft & support; 0.3mm layer height and "low" settings - 230 deg extrusion, 100 deg platform, 100 mm/s.  
Hide in the shrubbery... and wait...

comments.text: This is awesome thanks!  You saved me some time.  By the way, I had him tilted forward when I scanned him to make the face scan better, so thanks for rotating it back too!

comments.text:
You're welcome - it's a lovely scan and really made me laugh.
Interesting about the tilting - does the nose stop the two laser lines seeing the detail behind?
P.S. I liked amybuser's comment.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/2vfpqbMqKc5

I bought some paint mask for 1/35 tanks and I thought I could print my own for various vehicles. So this is my first set. Will do 8 wheels at a time. Handy as I have 32 Road wheels to paint on each Tiger. I am going to look at spraying a tacky contact on the indent where the tyre will rest so they stay in there by them selves. Should work well.

I made 6 test prints of one wheel mask till I was happy with the size and fit of the wheel then added 4 together and printed to test still ok. I need to change the roll of filament now so then I will print a couple of 8 Wheels capacity.
I will post some pics once I have finished printing them and test drive them.

author: albine92

description.text:
RefloLeo is a SMD toaster oven controller which recently gained funding through Kickstarter. made and sold by John Kicklighter, it allows toaster ovens tp be controlled to a set thermal graph, set by yourself, and stored on an SD card. I purchased a controller and it arrived in the post and i went away and made a case for it. Although this case is great, it does not allow tyou to screw it together, so it is a glue together. John, if your reading this, please place some fixing holes to allow people to mount it :) also change the reset switch to a tactile button switch, something like: http://bit.ly/GCm4LF
Also, the green 'on LED' make this a 90 degree LED, 0805, so it illuminates the keypad. also means its less likely to get knocked off. More information on Johns project can be found here:
http://www.kickstarter.com/projects/1034145369/refloleo

Print top case with top to heat bed.
Print bottom case with base to heat bed. Wire in connectors into RefloLeo controller (thermocouple, relay and fan (if using one)) Place inside RefloLeo PCB, and align onto bottom base. (additional, drill holes into top case if you wish to access terminal screws for relay, fan and thermocouple) place hot melt glue along edge of bottom case Place on top cover, aligning to edges and LCD. Use!

title: Qidi spool holder expander (for new metal type)

description.text: The new Qidi's have metal spool holders that are very nice. However, I have some really wide spools that wouldn't fit on the holders. I used Tinkercad and designed a new screw on cap that extends the depth of the spool holder.

comments.text:
This is a great idea and design. I use them on mine. The only problem I have found over time is the "bolt" eventually parts from the rest of the part. I think it is an inherent problem with 3D printing that where the bolt meets the base is just a weak, problem area. I have thought of a couple possible ways to strengthen that area.
Thanks again for a great part.

title: SCX-200 GoPro Yi HD Cam Mount

description.text:
A top mounted HD cam mount that I made for the SCX-200. I haven't flown mine yet, but this should fit just fine. Currently only in a 30 degree variant, but I will be updating the whole design within the coming days/weeks and adding different angles.

I printed in PLA at 50% infill and it weighs about 13g and seems pretty sturdy. I personally like my cam mount to break before my quad or my camera, so I might actually make it weaker.

As this is the first part I have ever made, please feel free to give me any and all suggestions and constructive criticism. Thanks for looking!

Max. Motor Voltage VBB 28V
Max. Logic Voltage VDD 5.5V
Max. Power Dissipation (no heatsink) 2.0 W
Default Vref voltage VDD x 0.267 +- 2%
Default Motor current Vref/2.16 +-10%
Rosc GND (mixed decay mode) MS1 MS2 Microstep Resolution Excitation Mode L L Full Step 2 Phase H L Half Step 1-2 Phase L H Quarter Step W1-2 Phase H H Sixteenth Step 4W1-2 Phase Table 1. Microstep Resolution Truth Table
  • Fixed by internal resistors 33K to VDD, 12K to GND, May be changed on pin VR

comments.text: Are there plans to release the actual source for this thing? PDF docs of the schematic and board layout aren't the best format for this type of thing. The file format chosen for publication seems to be in opposition to the beliefs expressed just two years ago. http://www.makerbot.com/blog/2010/03/25/open-source-ethics-and-dead-end-derivatives/http://www.makerbot.com/blog/2...
comments.author: ljyang

comments.text: I know peter_ is not searching for Pololu compatible PCB.
comments.author: Fishedbear

comments.text: These look pin compatible to the Pololu drivers except for the VR/MS3 pin.  Were they less expensive to mass manufacture, but left footprint compatible (?) incase someone needed a spare quickly?
comments.author: peter_

comments.text: Versus the Pololu A4988 pinouts, the VR (Voltage Reference) signal replaces the Microstep 3 signal.Â  This may make manually setting the current limit easier, since you can get the reference voltage off the connector rather than the wiper pot or the interior through hole.Â Â  It also enables easier off-board current limiting control.Â
comments.author: peter_

comments.text: How do they compare to the pololu in terms of power output? Thermal dissipation? Price? etc
comments.author: peter_

comments.text: This chip is nearly, but not quite identical to the one on the Pololu.  Exact same specifications except that it lacks a 1/8 microstep.  The pinout of this chip is 'friendlier', i.e., less prone to soldering errors.
comments.author: dmeehl

comments.text: Looks like they used the same chip as the pololu, possibly got them to design it for them.

Brushed micro-quad designed in collaboration with Michael Grabner of RCFPVFlight.com for FPV fun. This quad is designed to work with 8.5 mm brushed motors and a brushed controller. I use the Hubson x4 motors and controller but there are several other boards available. There are two main frames, one that is a perfect X and one with the front arms splayed out a bit to keep the props out of the camera view. There are three top plates as well, one basic, one with a mount for a micro camera and one without standoffs. I have also included a 20 degree camera mount designed for the Quanum ELITE TX CAMERA COMBO Micro Cam. If there is interest I will design other angles.

As always constructive feedback is encouraged

Update 6/9/16 Version 2.0 of both main plates have been uploaded. These new versions are much stronger and stiffer and fix a weak spot in the original design

The front camera mount was inspired by the micro 105 FPV Quadcopter

The Quanum camera mount was inspired by the Quanum ELITE TX CAMERA

author: Stephane10200

description.text:
e-NABLE Phoenix hand modified for Unlimbited arm application only. Sleeker, smoother and made to use monofilament tendons with crimps. It uses no dental bands for less effort to close fingers and thumb. Double strands of 80# test monofilament do the job of both pushing and pulling fingers for a more natural look at rest and excellent strength when closed.
The whipple tree is located in the palm. The tendons do not feed through standard Phoenix channels but go straight into the palm when assembling.
All files are at "100%" (child size) and should remain adequately consistent when matching percentages for all typical builds.
The "Chicago pin" is meant for wrist and cuff attachment. I print these in nylon for max strength. You will need to add a screw and washer.
I was unable to attribute John Diamond, Andreas Bastion and many others for their excellent work on the Phoenix Hand, but they deserve it! Here is the full attribution address: www.thingiverse.com/thing:1453190

comments.text: This design is being superceded soon with updated files. However, it will assemble much the same, i.e., like the Phoenix hand in terms of how fingers fit together (1 pin per joint at finger and then into palm with two short knuckle pins for 3rd and little finger and 1 long knuckle pin for 1st and 2nd fingers. The thumb is the same with the appropriate thumb pins. Once assembled, each finger and thumb get a strand of heavy duty monofilament that goes from the finger tip and straight into the inner palm, around one of the two wide portions of the whipple tree back out through the palm into the next finger and out through the finger tip. You will have one pair of fingers ( 1/2 or 3/4) attached around the whipple in the palm and finnished at each fingertip with an aluminum crimp. Try to make the length of each pair about the same so two sides of the whipple are close and equidistant from the palm. You can then use the solo side of the whipple to run one line all the way up through the arm and cuff to one tensioner. The thumb gets its own line all the way to the tensioner. You now have two lines controlling five fingers (instead of five) and the whipple tree allows all four fingers to grip proportionally - they will fit the shape  of the object being held.

I produced these for hanging on my beehives to identify a colony - useful for consistent record keeping. I've uploaded a blank version so different numbers can be used.

Using the Sketch project you can use the 3D text plugin to generate different text.

title: PanelDue 7 inch display enclosure and mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This my enclosure design for a PanelDue with 7 inch touch screen display.
Details of the PanelDue can be found at:-
http://escher3d.com/pages/order/products/product2.php

To enable the box to be printed on a 200mm wide printer the controller is mounted on the case lid behind the display. You will need a short M-F ribbon cable to do this. The cables are readily available as Raspberry Pi GPIO extenders.

The disadvantage of this is that to access the reset and erase buttons you need to remove the back cover, but as they are not normally needed in use, only for firmware loading, it isn't a problem.

The mount is for an Ormerod 2 but as it is bolted to the enclosure it would be easy to use an alternate mount.

Be careful when mounting the boards that the pillars do not split.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Ormerod 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Any

Infill:

20% for enclosure 60% for mount

Notes:

You may want to print in PLA if you have problems getting ABS to stick.

comments.text: What size/length screws did you use for mounting the controller to the bottom cover and the bracket_b part?
comments.author: ElmoC

comments.text: The PanelDue comes with a pair of screws. I added a fibre washer between the screwhead and board.  I seem to recall I used M4 screws for the bracket. I'm not sure of the length but I know I had to shorten the ones I had. For the hinge part of the bracket use an M4 self locking nut. The bolt from the original power unit stay can be re-used but It's a faff to get in place. A lump of blue tac in the extrusion stops the tee nut dropping while you get the bolt started.
comments.author: ElmoC

comments.text: Do you have a picture of the insides with everything mounted?  It looks like the buzzer would be inside, under the display for this to work.
comments.author: ElmoC

comments.text: You are correct that the buzzer on the PanelDue points to the main display pcb. On the USB side of the main case are some holes to allow the sound out at 90 degrees to the buzzer. In addition the vents on the back panel allow the sound out. The PanelDue buzzer can be set quite loud, so in practice there is no problem. I have mine set to medium and even with dodgy hearing I find it more than loud enough.
comments.author: ElmoC

remixed_from.author: mbthor
remixed_from.title: SCOUTcorexy 3D Printer (square aluminum tube frame, scout-tower-like corner nodes, dual-support Z, lots of adjustability to compensate for construction errors)

title: SCOUTcorexy XY_Stage XCarriage !!10mm!! YCarriage 10mm HorizontalRods SingleHotend

description.text:
NOTE: this is continuously being re-uploaded as i modify the design (which is very much in WIP) so make sure you come here often.

Update 17/06/2016: re-did the bearings block and the hotend mount now has detachable belt grippers for off-site clamping then insertion onto the carriage, the grippers are now printed separately ensuring correct orientation during printing. Some other modifications at the hotend-clamping bolts.

This is the 10mm XRods variation of the previous 8mm Rods XCarriage. It is designed for Bowden setups and Horizontal Rods, getting rid of most of the static and dynamic errors that affect printing during the accelerations/jerks/etc of a 3D printer (discussion here: http://forums.reprap.org/read.php?1,668254).

Sketchfab 3D model with exploded view here: https://skfb.ly/OVzz

DETAILS:

  • X uses 10mm rods and LM10UU bearings
  • Y uses 10mm rods and LM10UU bearings
  • belt is gt2
  • Hotend is a clone of E3Dv6
  • axial fans are 30mm
  • radial blowers are 4020 type
  • all in all the XCarriage is very symmetrical and any forces applied during accelerations, jerks, etc, are evenly distributed so that the nozzle remains as fixed as possible.

Features:

  • 72.75mm XCarriage (the Belt-Catchers go inside the YCarriages so they are not wasted space);
  • Belts go in straight line and in the same plane from YCarriages towards the XCarriage;
  • Belts can be tensioned with simple screws and dome-nuts pressing on the belt, forcing it into the niche designed for it; belts can be independently tensioned;
  • Hotend supported both upside carriage and lower side by the 4 screws;
  • Dual-30mm fans for coldend cooling;
  • Dual-30mmfan (or squirrelcage blowers) for part cooling [still very undecided here];

TBD:
1) some way to remove wiggle/play from the linear bearings
2) design it for dual hotend
[...]

Cheers,
Flo.

Modified BearingBlock BasePart

Uodate1: Modified BearingBlock_Base and removed the extra plastic around the hotend for no actual purpose other than some extra reinforcement. Now the air from fans can more easily get to the lower, hotter fins. Still not the best way to cool the lower fins.

description.text:
I published an improved version which simplifies the built significantly!

Experimenting a bit more with spiral design and wood bending, this small bowl came to life. It turned out, that a little fixation using small brackets is needed.

My build was done on a desktop cnc-machine by Stepcraft from 6 mm birch plywood using a spiral-toothed 1.2 mm flute.

I used Illustrator and a script written by Sato Hiroyuki to create an approach of the Archimedes Spiral.

author: x3x3x

title: Spyda 500 Quadcopter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Create a "spider style" Quadcopter. ideal for FPV flying to keep the props out of shot. It is also much easier to keep visually orientated in the sky. Two versions of this thing :
  • A central plate for the stock DJI 450 Flamewheel arms or you can print an optimised one supplied (without support).
  • A central plate for the Crossfire printable arms (included) from MikeyB. Plus I include a re-mixed thicker version of these arms if you want to increase the plate distance.
    • Props are positioned on a 500mm diameter circle, hence the name. The central plates are large enough to mount a variety of components. See my remixes for extra mountable components, eg GoPro Flexy Gimbal, standard GoPro mount and accessory pack 1st flight test video with a bit of FPV in there :
    https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=W-BDJv8o308
    And a bit more flying over Uffington White Horse, Oxfordshire, UK:
    https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QHCpInwQhQ0 Vertigo-blues has done a vibration analysis on his Spyda quad : http://www.vertigo-blues.com/3d-printed-spyda-500-apm-vibration-analysis/ EDIT 24/04/2014 : Uploaded a stronger V3 DEEJAYEYE arm with larger fillet at foot connection. Uploaded STEP file of arm and SPYDA DEEJAYEYE QUAD plate by request.
    EDIT 24/01/2014 : Uploaded a stronger V2 DEEJAYEYE arm kindly remixed in this thing by Andycap.
    EDIT 05/12/2013 : Uploaded DXF files for laser cutting.
    EDIT 30/11/2013 : Uploaded a printable DJI replica arm.
    EDIT 12/11/2013 : Added solid plate versions without the stiffening webs, for those who maybe want to mount components both sides. (with and without slot options).

Print x2 off whichever plate you require.  
The plates can be mounted either way up according to which side you want to mount components too.  
Note : The plate for the Crossfire arms has slightly modified geometry, the motors are still on a 500mm Dia circle but the 380mm and 325mm dimensions from the drawing are 390mm and 313 resp.  
The next step is for me to design a servo based GoPro Hero3 gimbal, so watch this space.

For those of you flying with the kk2 boards you must change the motor layout in the mixer settings. But first make sure your control board is always centered over the center of gravity, indicated most of the time by the rear center hole on the plates. Because the motors are not at 45 degrees to the frame you must tell the board where they are.
My settings are:
Channel 1
Aileron: -77
Elevator: 64

comments.text: Hi, great write up, many thanks. I am not entirely sure how your flight controller is configured. If you can get the centre of gravity close to the centre of the 500 diameter circle then this is the best balance option. This depends on where your mount batteries camera etc. The centre is defined by the small hole in the plate (see drawing). However, wherever the COG is positioned, as long as the flight controller has accelerometers, it will still adjust to give a steady and stable flight, it's just that some motors will be working a little harder than others and flight time might be compromised.

Has anyone used them before to have one printed and what would be the cost? Also, I'm not 100% clear on what type of filament to ask for and thickness. Also, what is the difference between the Crossfire board and the Deejayeye? Which arms are the better of the ones listed?
comments.author: pekwalker

comments.text: Glad you like the design, maybe try 3Dhubs first (http://www.3dhubs.com/)http://www.3dhubs.com/) there are a few printers localish to yourself. The Crossfire is also a fully printable Quad which was release before the Spyda, and the board in this thing will accept the arms from the Crossfire (which I have included). The Deejayeye board will accept the stock arms that you can buy from a quad manufacture called DJI, in case you wanted to do an upgrade to my Spyda design from a DJI 450. However I also include a model of a printable Deejayeye arm incase you wanted to also print this too. Which is best, I am really not sure I have only built my quad with the shop purchased (actually Ebay) DJI arms and these haven't broke yet. And there is also the Spyda Hexacopter too ;-) http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:241977http://www.thingiverse.com/thi...
comments.author: pekwalker

Any smaller and the props will hit each other, Any larger and it will probably be laser cut only for all but the largest printers. Or we could print longer DJI style arms if we want smaller plates or larger props, too many options..........
Cheers
Steve.

description.text:
Band saw boxes are boxes made out of wood using only a bandsaw for cutting them out. The wood may be a solid block, a laminated block or a log from the woodpile. Whereas most boxes have straight sides and square corners, band saw boxes have virtually no restrictions as to shape.

I've just discovered this style of box and thought it would be great to create a 3D printable version - so here it is.

Band saw boxes are normally cut from laminated blocks, so my filament interpretation uses black PLA and ColorFabb Woodfill http://colorfabb.com/woodfill-fine. I also had to change black filament spools mid print, hence the gloss and matt 'blacks'.

I've included two sets of drawers: with supports and without. Use whichever works for you.

Enjoy!

description.text:
Parakeet uses a SIMM800L rather than a cell phone to Upload Data to Nightscout.

About:

This case was influenced by Lehaiver's xDrip Wireless Bridge case v1.7 for the Nightscout/xDrip project: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1481048

Assembly:

I have a pretty basic printer that does not do well with overhangs so, boards could only be located. I used Epoxy to secure the boards in place and CA ( instant glue ) for the cover. Switch height is critical. The Switch should NOT open or close when the case is laid face down on a flat surface. The thru hole is meant to be drilled to final size.

Use CA to glue ring to Battery Door. Check and adjust Door fit to case. I left this intentionally "tight". It opens easily by wedging a utility knife blade between the door and case. Attach 3.0mm thick foam to the bottom of ring. Foam should contact battery and not let door deflect.

Refer to project page for electronics assembly instructions.

Once you have the electronics assembly wired, double check your connections and place it in a cast iron frying pan away from anything flammable. Be careful not to short anything out. Insulate if necessary. Fully charge the Lithium battery. Power up, Check operation. Your battery should not get hot.

Mount electronics in Case and secure with epoxy.

I secured the back cover with masking tape and tested for a couple of days to confirm operation before gluing it permanently in place.

Project Documentation:

Parakeet Project Page
https://jamorham.github.io/#parakeet

What is the Parakeet ?
https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B6mvYVNVC-fOQU5XQS14NERwYjA/view?pref=2&pli=1

Parakeet Project Documentation
https://github.com/jamorham/wixel-xDrip

Video set-up instructions
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sq1Vs4Vor7c
The You Tube video made by Andrew Abramowicz is well put together - complete and VERY helpful. However, I couldn't get my Wixel FW to compile using "make_all.bat". So, I ended up using the "MAKE" command from S. Black's xDrip documentation https://github.com/StephenBlackWasAlreadyTaken/wixel-xDrip (How do I use it ? Step 3:). This may just be a Windows 10.xx issue.

title: Malyan M180 Y--axis belt tensioner
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
When printing with my M180 I found that the y-axis wasn't steady, this could be seen on the test cube 20x20 and when printing a round wall of only 2 extrusions. In the cube case the corners were not correct a notch was on 2 opposite corners. in the round wall case one could see a separation of the extrusions on 2 opposite locations, this was where the y-axis changed direction. When the printer does extrusion clockwise and counterclockwise this is very clear.
The problem that causes this is not enough tension on the y-axis belt. On my printer I could not create enough tension by sliding the stepper motor down. So the solution had to be to create some device that will increase the tension. The result is a wheel with GT2 teeth that rides in the middle of the belt, this increases the tension on the belt.
I've provided 1 34 and 1 36 teeth wheel.
To mount the wheel, you will have to loosen the stepper motor and put in the wheel, when tension is applied to the belt will stay in the location where you have put.

Printer Brand:

Robo 3D

Printer:

R1 ABS + PLA Model

author: axelfrom

description.text:
The Prusa i3 is really a great design. The only thing I have problem with is the way the x belt is tensioned. Since the x smooth rods are not clamped in the x end, the belt tension is actually on the z smooth rods. I probably have some low quality smooth rods but for me it tends to bend the z smooth rods so I cannot put much tension on the belt. The ugly x-end you see on the picture is the result of this lack of tension on the x belt.  
This part is a quick and dirty upgrade which reuses all the original part and just adds a plate to put the load on the x axis smooth rods instead of loading the z axis.  
It uses 2 M6 bolts and nuts. The M4 nut in the middle is the original one from the Prusa i3 idler holder. The bolt holding the idler holder in the x end is removed.

comments.text: Thank You. This solved a design flaw in the i3 kit that I purchased. Makes the Z axis movement a lot smoother.
comments.author: DaveOB

comments.text: This solved my no Z axis movement during printing. Thanks, this saved me from wanting to toss my printer out a window.
comments.author: zerodameaon

comments.text: hehe, good! I am glad it saved your printer from flying :-)
comments.author: zerodameaon

comments.text: Great design ffleurey, i hade the same problem you experienced, when i increased the tension the two z rods deformed just a little and that turned into a z wobble problem since che distance between the smooth and threaded bars wasn't consistent.
comments.author: Nova

comments.text:
This is very interesting!
Did it improve the quality of your printer?
comments.author: odino

comments.text: Yes, I believe it did improve my prints because it allows to have more (or more consistent) tension on the X belt. Before this upgrade I was affraid to put too much tension on the belt because the Z rods were deforming. Difficult to tell how visible the improvements are but now the x belt tension can be adjusted without side effects :-)

This is a simple sonar mount for EZ-Robot. In the example pictures I designed it for clipping onto my robot's arm above the gripper. It has a male ez-bit for connecting to parts from http://www.ez-robot.com

Several versions are included here for forward facing sensors, meaning the sensor is as the front of the ez-bit, or reversed, meaning that the sensor is as the back of the ez-bit. There are also flat versions that could be glued on your robot instead of using the male ez-bit.

The sensor will mount with a small bolt and nut that you will need to supply. Or you could use a dab of hot glue.

This is a little holder for a Karma Go hotspot (full disclosure: that's an affiliate link that gives you and me a $10 discount). The device slots in and fits snugly. The status lights are visible on top, and the charging port and power button are accessible on the side. The back of the holder is flat, so it's easily mountable with double-sided tape.

I use this in our family van, so the kids can watch Netflix during road trips, and the hotspot doesn't take up any precious space in the tiny dashboard compartment, yet can remain plugged into the charger. I'd previously tried just using velcro, but the constant vibration meant the device would randomly detach itself and roll across the floor. Kind of scary when it rolls under the brake pedal. This holder should keep it secure while still making it possible to easily remove the device when actually desired.

This holder may also work with the FreedomPop Freedom Spot Photon and Clear Spot Voyager, as they seem to have the same form-factor, but I have not tested either of them with this holder — I've never even seen them in person.

title: Camera tripod to PVC 1/2" pipe bracket

description.text:
This is a bracket to join a piece of 1/2" PVC to a camera tripod. Camera tripods typical use 1/4"-20 bolts and the center vertical hole is sized to fit a coupler I found at my local hardware store for $1. Using a washer on the 1" bolt causes the entire assembly to be under compression to help resist the torque of whatever you attach to the bracket.
Note: Print orientation matters here! See notes.

To assemble:

  1. Place 1/2" PVC pipe section inside bracket. Depending on your print settings, this may be a very tight fit. That's good, but may result in having to use some percussive encouragement to get the pipe centered in the bracket.
  2. Use bracket's coupler hole as a jig to drill out a 1/2" hole in the PVC
  3. Screw a 1/4"-20 bolt into one end of the bolt coupler with a large washer under it.
  4. Insert coupler into vertical hole and through PVC
    • If your print has any slop in it, insert short screws into the two screw holes on the side. You may also wish to cement the coupler in place with some hot glue or similar.
  5. Screw tripod into open end of coupler.
  6. ???
  7. Profit!

Printer:

MiniMax

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.4mm if you can, but nothing wrong with lower.

Infill:

20%

Notes:

This shouldn't be too picky, but you do want to print it so that the thinner hole is perpendicular to your build plate. This will allow the bolt to greatly increase the strength of the print.

description.text: A 3d printed Bell Siphon that works from the getgo!

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 5

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.5

Infill:

20

Notes:

Used Brim

Designed in the mind

Visit:
Intservo: http://www.intservo.com

My website: http://getwireddaily.com/

Design, Most likely the biggest step in the process while also being the easiest. Currently, I offer the design that I made through several mediums such as Thingiverse and Shapeways so that you can print the device yourself. If you choose to make your own model I recommend that you search various types of the bell siphon or simply copy the design that I have. I believe that I explain it thoroughly enough on the video for a proper reconstruction. The model that I use is rather simplistic in terms of bell siphons but works nonetheless. Further additions to this model can be done such as adding a rock/gravel guard depending on the situation. As it stands the model should work fine in most situations while being fully automated. I would also like to point out that I do not know how long the siphon will operate and may truly be dependent on circumstances such as algae build up.

The bell siphon has five main sections; siphon pipe, drain pipe, snorkel, cap, and the pipe stand. I have integrated all of these parts into a single object allowing the printer to make water tight seal. This is extremely important as any leaks in the print will cause the siphon to not function.

As it stands the siphon can be as large as you want given that the printer can accommodate the size. I have not personally tried a multipart print, but I would assume that this would cause an issue given the need for a perfect seal on each part. I recommend that if a part needs to be long then they simply stretch the model to their maximum print capacity. If the siphon needs to drain faster than simply print more than one siphon so they work in conjunction. If a multi siphon system is made it is important that all siphons are equally leveled so that the vacuum process starts simultaneously on each siphon.

Print that bad boy

Skip this step if you don't have access to a printer or you just wanna see the final step either is cool :D

The picture is the inside section of the Cap/SiphonStand with the (broken)snorkel attached on the side.

I use a lulzbot printer with a 0.5mm Nozzle with PLA+ filament from eSun. Settings for printer are as follows:

Rafts:No

Supports:No

Infill:20%

Speed setting: Fast

Brim:Yes

Temp:210

BedTemp:60

Adhesive to print bed:Purple Glue

Anxiety: High

Test your dream

The moment of truth has finally come but you can feel your gut sinking thinking, "Did I just waste 4+ hours printing on a siphon that has a chance to not work, based solely on some stranger on the internet?" The answer to that is yes, yes you did...But the siphon should work! At least I hope it does :D...If the siphon works then congratulations! If not then thank you for calling ComCast customer service how may service you today?

Troubleshooting:

Siphon doesn't work:

Take siphon and blow through the drain outlet. Does air hit you in the face? Good that means its working that way. Put the siphon in a cup of water so that the snorkel is submerged, but the Bell isn't under water. Blow into the outlet drain again and look for bubbles popping up around the cylinder. If there are bubbles then you have a hole somewhere. The snorkel will be the only area with bubbles coming out. if this is the case I recommend reprinting the snorkel or gluing the holes closed.

Siphon doesn't drain all the way:

Attach a hose or extension to the bottom of the drain pipe.

Siphon doesn't stop at snorkel:

The snorkel is clogged... clean it...Or print a new one!

This wasn't funny at all:

Neither is Comcast customer service...So...
